Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Learning About New Demands in Schools: Considering Algebra Policy Environments [LANDSCAPE]

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The main purpose of the proposed study is to investigate and report on how school districts are responding to the universal early algebra demand. This is in response to the pressures on school districts to have all students complete Algebra I, or its equivalent, by grade 9. A survey will be administered to a national sample of school districts to gather information on what policies the district has on students taking Algebra I and how these policies are being implemented. Case studies will be performed for 12 of the school districts surveyed to produce more detailed information on the policy, what decisions are made for placing students in different formats of the Algebra I course, and how teachers are selected to teach these courses. The work will be done by researchers at Michigan State University in collaboration with researchers at the University of Pennsylvania. Information generated from this project will inform policy (district as well as national) related to STEM education and for influencing students' opportunities to learn particularly relevant to underrepresented students who are most frequently affected by policies related to algebra.

A survey will be constructed and administered to one knowledgeable person at each of the 1365 selected school districts. The districts will be selected from clusters defined by existing state graduation requirements for mathematics. Questions on the survey will seek responses to what pressures district leadership have for universal early algebra and ways the district is responding to these pressures. Case studies will be conducted at 12 school districts to gather more specific information on curricular, human resources, organizational, and assessment strategies that are being employed. The project will be supported by two mathematics education consultants and an advisory board. An evaluator will examine the procedures and will provide both formative and summative feedback along with an independent report on the progress of the project.

Findings from the study will be disseminated to a broad array of audiences through presentations, research journal articles, and policy briefs that will be widely available. The findings are likely to be of great interests at the national, state, and district levels and inform policy as the nation struggles to increase the rigor and proportion of students who graduate from high school and are college and career ready.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The goal of the Learning About New Demands in Schools: Considering Algebra Policy Environments [LANDSCAPE] project was to investigate district-level algebra policy and practices. Specifically, the project investigated the structures and tools that districts use to make a first secondary course in Algebra (typically Algebra I) available to middle and high school students.  Algebra I has been described as a gatekeeper that either permits or restricts students’ access to future mathematical study. Learning the content of algebra can support students to be successful problem solvers and prepares them both for college and career futures. Typically, Algebra I has been taken in 9th grade. Recent trends have moved toward expanding enrollments in 8th grade to provide students opportunities to take calculus in high school.   The study had two main parts.  The project developed and conducted a survey of a nationally- representative sample of school districts in the United States about their Algebra I policy and practice. The project also included case studies of twelve school districts, three in each of four major metropolitan areas across the United States, to delve more deeply into  Algebra I policies and practices.

Previous policy analyses and rhetoric have suggested that there is a national push through state and district policy to enroll more students in Algebra I in the 8th grade.  Districts reported increases in Algebra I enrollment in 8th grade over a five-year period, but we found no evidence to suggest a broad policy push towards 8th grade Algebra I.  Districts reported an average of 25% of eighth grade students enrolled in Algebra I and an average of 70% of ninth grade students enrolled in Algebra I. This means that taking Algebra I in 9th grade remains the most common practice for most US districts.  When asked about their decision-making process for placing students into Algebra I,, the majority of districts reported use of local measures, like teacher recommendations and course grades compared to broader or more standardized criteria. This suggests individual teachers have the most influence over when students have access to algebra.

When we asked districts about how they assessed student success and supported students during Algebra I, districts tended to maintain local control and implement flexible and adaptive approaches to algebra course offerings and assessment. Districts use state policy as a starting point, but often tailor algebra policies locally. The curriculum materials landscape was dominated by traditional publisher-authored curricula that are not likely to meet the rigorous reasoning and problem solving demands of the Common Core or other similar mathematics standards. When asked about teacher professional development, district leaders noted that time for mathematics-specific professional development was limited to less than 2 days per year on average. District leaders also tended to believe that there is a developmental readiness for Algebra I, which contrasts with current research findings. When asked about issues of access and equity, districts with more diverse students were more likely to consider issues of access and equity when determining Algebra I policy and practice.

With respect to the twelve case study districts, we found that nearly every district (11 of 12) offered some form of Algebra I at both the middle and high school levels.  All twelve districts also had multiple Algebra I tracks, which represented differences in content and pacing intended for different perceived ability groups of students.  An analysis of the mathematics being taught in the different Algebra I courses revealed no differences between middle and high school courses. Some differences did arise between perceived ability group classes, with higher-track courses containing more content aligning to high school standards as compared to lower-track courses.  The majority of twelve districts were concerned about preventing underprepared students from enrolling in algebra before high school. Few districts, however, were concerned about not enrolling students who may be successful in algebra. Many case study district decision-makers expressed a belief in the importance of students’ developmental readiness for success in algebra.

Overall, this study finds that most districts are offering Algebra I both to 9th graders and middle school students, with 9th grade still being the most common year to take the course. Decisions about which students take the Algebra I course and what constitutes success are largely local decisions.  District leaders seem to rely on concepts of developmental readiness that are not supported by current research.  The content of Algebra I in the case study districts does seem to be consistent across grade levels, but not across ability-tracked classes.  This results in differences in students’ opportunities to learn the content of Algebra I based on their prior performance and perceptions of their mathematics abilities. Full report can be found at http://cpre.org/landscape.
